title: Henri Bergson
summary: Henri-Louis Bergson (French: [bɛʁksɔn]; 18 October 1859 – 4 January 1941) was a French philosopher[7][8][9][10][11] who was influential in the tradition of continental philosophy, especially during the first half of the 20th century until the Second World War.[12] Bergson is known for his arguments that processes of immediate experience and intuition are more significant than abstract rationalism and science for understanding reality.
